name: Andrews–Curtis conjecture
rephrased: The Andrews–Curtis conjecture states that any way of writing the 'empty product' (trivial group) using an equal number of starting symbols (generators) and equations (relations) can be transformed into a presentation showing no relations by applying a series of specific operations (Nielsen transformations on generators and relations, plus conjugating relations).
implication_form: If a balanced presentation represents the trivial group, then it can be transformed into a trivial presentation (one with no relations) using a series of Nielsen transformations and conjugations.
posed_by: James J. Andrews and Morton L. Curtis
explained: The Andrews–Curtis conjecture states that any balanced presentation (i.e., a presentation with the same number of generators and relations) of the trivial group (the group with a single identity element) is an 'Andrews–Curtis trivial presentation'. This means it can be transformed into the presentation with no generators and no relations (the trivial presentation) by a series of operations known as Nielsen transformations applied to the generators and relators, and by conjugating the relators.
